metadata.synopsis: Director Alan Berliner has a problem: He can't sleep. For much of his life, Berliner has been plagued by insomnia. It's left an indelible impact on both his career as a filmmaker and his personal relationships. In this documentary, Berliner examines his condition and his long, futile search for a good night's sleep. He talks with his family and a panoply of doctors and uses a meticulous assemblage of vintage film clips to illustrate his own disjointed mental state come bedtime.

reviews: It's possibly Alan Berliner's most personal documentary ever.
To make a personal documentary click, you really have to be willing to get in the trenches with the subject and that just doesn't happen here.
A fascinatingly self-indulgent look at one man's battle with insomnia.
No one will be nodding out at Wide Awake.
The film plays like an open window on the mind of an obsessed and tortured artist.
